sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 0.1m carrying a current of 2A is placed in a uniform magnetic field of 0.5T. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at the center of the circular loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at the center of the circular loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop carrying a current:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop (in this case, x = 0 since we are calculating the magnetic field at the center of the loop).

Plugging in the given values:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * (0.1 m)²)^(3/2)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm²) / (0.1 m)²

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm²) / 0.01 m²

B = 8π × 10^(-5) T

B ≈ 2.51 × 10^(-4) T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the center of the circular loop is approximately 2.51 × 10^(-4) T.

As for the direction of the magnetic field, it will be perpendicular to the plane of the circular loop. To determine whether it is pointing upwards or downwards, we can use the right-hand rule. Curl your right hand's fingers in the direction of the current (counterclockwise in this case), and your thumb will point in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will be pointing upwards (out of the plane of the loop).
